channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.N. Report Faults Countries’ Efforts to Curb Domestic Violence
item.description: One in four children have been physically abused, and one in five girls have been sexually abused, according to findings from a survey of 133 countries.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: UKIP, a Proponent of British Values, Faces a Sex Scandal
item.description: In a blow to its image, the U.K. Independence Party has suspended its general secretary after he was accused of sexual harassment.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Zimbabwe Leader Picks Hard-Liner as Vice President
item.description: President Robert G. Mugabe has appointed a former security strongman nicknamed the Crocodile to replace his dismissed vice president.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Verdict Can Be Appealed, Judge Says
item.description: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa allowed an appeal against the athlete’s acquittal on murder charges, but not against his five-year sentence.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Amid Denuciations of Torture, Some Praise for U.S. Openness
item.description: The Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, said the C.I.A. abuses “violated all accepted norms of human rights in the world.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Siberian Tiger, Freed to Roam by Putin, Returns From China Sojourn
item.description: Russian and Chinese conservationists said Kuzya, one of three rescued cubs that President Vladimir V. Putin had released, had crossed a frozen river between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Cost of Living Takes Center Stage in Israeli Elections
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is worried not about his credentials on security issues, but about voters’ concerns that Israel is getting too expensive.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Parliament on Monday. He pledged to eliminate taxes on food staples if re-elected.

item.title: Kabul Journal: For Afghans, Name and Birthdate Census Questions Are Not So Simple
item.description: Culture is a census obstacle: Many Afghans lack surnames, most do not know their birthday, and women will not speak if their husbands are out.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghans waiting on Tuesday at the Population Registration Division in Kabul. The last census in Afghanistan took place in 1979, and the government now aims to count and register citizens, and to issue them new identification cards.

item.title: Liu Xiaobo, Nobel-Winning Chinese Dissident, Said to Send Message From Prison
item.description: A Berlin-based friend of Liu Xiaobo, who is serving an 11-year sentence in Beijing, said he had a received a message from him through contacts in China.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and IAN JOHNSON

item.title: As Hong Kong Occupy Protests Wind Down, Many Make One Last Visit
item.description: Protesters and others seeking to bear witness went to a pro-democracy encampment on Wednesday night, hours before the police planned to clear it.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Protesters packed their belongings in the occupied area near government headquarters in Hong Kong on Wednesday.

item.title: Palestinian Official Dies During Demonstration in West Bank
item.description: Witnesses said Ziad Abu Ein, 55, was struck and shoved by an Israeli soldier and inhaled tear gas, an event that raised tensions between Israelis and Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and SAID GHAZALI
item.media:description: Ziad Abu Ein, left, protesting against Israeli settlements in the village of Turmus Aya on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Young, Idealistic and Caught Up in a Wave of Detentions
item.description: About 10 people loosely connected with two nongovernmental organizations in China appear to have been detained, including a recently graduated lawyer who was setting up a legal aid group.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Liu Jianshu and his wife, Zhao Sile. She received a mailed notice of his criminal detention on Dec. 1 and has not been able to see him since.

item.title: Letter From India: Before Accusations, Uber Was a Boon for Indian Women
item.description: Uber is staying put, and by making it illicit, the government has probably relieved the company of the pressure to ensure the safety of its users.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: Letter From India: Before Accusations, Uber Was a Boon for Indian Women
item.description: Halting Uber in the Delhi region very likely eases pressure on the Indian authorities to ensure the safety of its users.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: Overseas, Torture Report Prompts Calls for Prosecution
item.description: Jihadist web postings called for retaliation, and the United States warned citizens in Thailand and Afghanistan about hostile reactions.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Malala Yousafzai and Kailash Satyarthi Receive Nobel Peace Prizes
item.description: The Pakistani youth and the Indian rights campaigner were named winners in October, a choice that seemed to speak to a desire to transcend differences in a common cause.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Armenia Wins Backing to Join Trade Bloc Championed by Putin
item.description: Russia’s lower house of Parliament voted to allow the former Soviet republic to join the Eurasian Economic Union.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Obama Avoids Taking Sides on Effectiveness of C.I.A. Techniques
item.description: The debate over interrogation techniques has left President Obama facing an uncomfortable choice between two allies: the C.I.A. director versus Democrats on the committee that produced the report.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: “We are not going to engage in this debate,” said a senior administration official close to President Obama.

item.title: A Top Target of China’s Antigraft Campaign Gets Life in Prison
item.description: Liu Tienan was one of the first and most visible targets of the push by President Xi Jinping to take down both “tigers” and “flies” — powerful and minor officials.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: U.N. Agency Reports More Refugees on the Sea, and Fewer Welcome Shores
item.description: Wars in places like Somalia and Syria are in part leading to more boat people at a time when anti-foreigner sentiment in Europe is growing.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
